Hi Daniel,we also talked about this in [0].

I am agree with you and zhanghao,it isn't good way to get QoS infomation from port_object.


I think the orginal problem of this is that QoS policy has not a direct releated resource in core OVN. 

I think the best way is to make a connection from UUID of qos policy of neutron and QoS row of core OVN. The probelm is how to record the UUID in core OVN, I think we can add a "name" column in QoS table of core OVN to do it, so I summit [1]. Han Zhou suggest me to make use of [2] to make the UUIDs be the same between neutron and Core OVN,but this patch colud not support ovn-*ctl commands, so I summit [3].

I think we have three ways to solve this.
1. As zhanghao says,we could record new and old qos policy in port and network. This just need to change neutron code.

2.Make the UUIDs be the same between neutron and Core OVN, this need to wait my patch[3] to merge, I think it needs a long time, and we need do much work on ovsdbapp.

3.If we record UUID of qos policy of neutron in external_ids of QoS in core OVN is not a bad choice,though I think it will be costly when search the target,but we have done many similar features. It need to change ovsdbapp and neutron. I think it is not complicated, and is a suitable way to do.

What do you think?

This could be a misleading exception if the failure is for any reason other than failure to communicate with the placement API ... but maybe there is some precedent for this that I don't know about.

Also, looking at the code for get_allocation_candidates, if there is a problem retrieving the allocation candidates, it will return (None, None, None) [1] which would not evaluate to False AFAICT. So I think the "if not res:" needs to be a different condition. Not sure if there's any other option than "if res == (None, None, None)".

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/171138146a648d22474b7021ac730e26f03455f8/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L314

Oh, wow, that is quite obscure, at least for me. I think it would be worthy of a code comment as it would make it clear it is about @safe_connect.

IIRC there was a desire to remove @safe_connect from the code altogether eventually, if that happened, we would need to change the logic here. (Just another reason why I think having a code comment would be helpful.)

It is unfortunately complicated. 

There is a safe_connect decorator on get_allocation_candidates that returns None if the connection failed [1].

In case of any other failure that is actually reported by placement, the return value will be (None, None, None). So both the placement-returned-error and the no-allocation-candidate-exists cases are handled at L1677-L1679 based on the returned tree tuple. While the connection failure handled here.

So I think the logic and the raised exception is correct here.


[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/171138146a648d22474b7021ac730e26f03455f8/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L74-L93

validations_libs/utils.py.message:
Do we need to use the pathlib?
The module provides substantial benefits only when it comes to deployment on non-unix OS.
In our case, when we are only running on Linux distros, we can stick with the os.path module[2].

Which we are using already in several places.

If we are aiming for compatibility with non-unix systems we would have to refactor all of the existing uses of the 'os.path'.

https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/os.path.html?highlight=path#module-os.path

Pathlib is not only providing benefits when it comes to deployment on non-Posix OS. But as it is an object-oriented filesystem paths library and do not derive from a builtin type. The file paths can be represented by proper Path objects instead of plain strings as with the os.path module. 

These objects make code dealing with file paths:
- Easier to read, especially because / is used to join paths together
- More powerful, with most necessary methods and properties available directly on the object
- More consistent across operating systems, as peculiarities of the different systems are hidden by the Path object. 

Yes you are right about the third point (OS consistency) but the two first items are very interesting to use IMO.
I'm not sure about putting this variable in a module scope. Instead it would be better to keep it within the recursive function.

This function is only used in one place and for a single purpose: to run 'ansible-galaxy' init. 

I would prefer something less general, we don't really need the ability to execute an arbitrary  command.

Is the recursion essential? We already know that none of the required directories is present if there is no basedir. 

So when we detect the at the base directory is missing we can just create entire tree immediately with [1]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/os.html?highlight=mkdir#os.makedirs

No the recursion is actually not essential, your are right.

This function is not recursive anymore in the last patch set.

The 'dir' is a Python builtin function [0]

We shouldn't overload it, if at all possible.

[0]https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/functions.html?highlight=dir#dir


and this happens because the dbus-daemon isn't there, so it's expected (and the right thing to do) to see the deployment failing.
Manila uses dbus to interact with the ganesha daemon provided by the ceph-nfs container, however, if the daemon isn't there, Manila can't be properly configured and it fails.
The daemon is present in c8s (Tripleo scenario004), which is green, but not in the rdo scenario004 job provided by testproject [3].

Had another look at this. 

Deletion of a branch triggers a single `repo:push` webhook like the above (note that `old` is a full object not just `{}`).

Merging a PR triggers two `repo:push` webhooks at the same moment. One, exactly like the above with the `old` referring to the branch in PR and a `null` `new`. The second referring to the branch receiving the merged PR as the `old` and the `new`.

The bug describes the circular dependency detected between vs_config and Service['openvswitch'] and we avoid notification to Service['openvswitch'] here.
Btw is vswitch::ovs and vswitch::dpdk mutually exclusive? Or should we ensure "restart openvswitch" exec does not cause a redeclaration issue?
Fixed typo + rebased on master as my change is no longer relevant.

These two are mutually exclusive. The parameters managed by these two parameters are overlapping. In RHEL/CentOS these two classes install the same openvswtich package which results in duplicated declaration.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
In projects like cinder, we require the list of conflicts to immediately follow the corresponding "cherry picked from" line, so my advice is to move the list so it follows L26 (with no intervening blank line).

The reason for doing it that way is it lets you correlate the list of conflicts with the associated cherry pick, and supports multiple conflict lists in situations where the patch is backported across multiple releases. For example, if this patch were a candidate for backporting to ussuri, you might need to resolve a different set of conflicts.

Hmm... I went through the other repos but that usage is not yet very common (even in cinder) so I reverted back the change with additional notes assuming it's be better to stick on conventional practice for now to keep "consistency" here.

On the other hand I personally agree with that idea and I think it's very good improvement. Maybe we can raise that topic to openstack-discuss ml to hear whether the other projects also like the idean and they are interested in introducing that as part of commin basic guideline.

I guess maybe it's more of a downstream convention for my team. I'm not optimistic about getting consensus in the wider community to adopt almost any kind of coding/comment style (everyone has an opinion), which is why I offered the idea as just a suggestion. Your latest patch set looks fine.

Ah I was not aware of that practice but that makes sense. I usually end up with adding a second conflicts note but adding it to the bottom sounds much simpler.

I'll update the patch to follow that and let's see how the other reviewers respond to that.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: leave off the "an oversight on my end"
By not using the bundled version of ebtables, do you think anything in the new iptables may not work?  In other words, is there any apparent reason why they bundle that version of ebtables?

Ah, unfortunately I do not know for sure. My understanding is that the new/iptables version of ebtables is expected to be a drop-in replacement for the legacy ebtables, but I was concerned about a potential regression.

Still though, it might be good to go with the iptables version of ebtables:

As an example, CentOS 8 Stream no longer ships the legacy ebtables (there is no src.rpm for it):
  https://vault.centos.org/8-stream/BaseOS/Source/SPackages/

As another example, Debian defaults to the version of ebtables bundled with iptables.

Note the comment in the following quote from the postinst file in legacy ebtables's Debian package, acquired from https://packages.debian.org/bullseye/iptables

```
# Providing alternatives with lower priority than those provided by iptables >= 1.8
if [ "$1" = "configure" ] || [ "$1" = "abort-upgrade" ]; then
    update-alternatives \
        --install /usr/sbin/ebtables ebtables /usr/sbin/ebtables-legacy 10 \
...
```

(I took a look, and iptables's version of ebtables has a higher priority passed to update-alternatives: 20.)

Any thoughts?

This would be something that I would run past a pt such as Matt Peters for his opinion.  If the two are normally bundled together, I would tend to worry more about using a legacy version of ebtables with the new iptables as that combo has likely not seen much use out there in the rest of the world.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
The use of pipeline manager sense.

Technically you can promote any item in any kind of pipeline.  But since it just moves it up to the top of the change queue, it doesn't shift position in an independent pipeline; but it does restart jobs.  In a supercedent or serial pipeline it would probably do the wrong thing, in that it would publish artifacts out of order.

So I think I agree that it probably makes sense to only show it in the UI for a dependent pipeline.  And if we want to expose a "restart" feature, we should actually just make a new feature rather than abusing promote for that, since while it would be okay for independent, it would be detrimental for serial/supercedent.

I'm a bit conflicted on the triggers.  It's entirely possible to have a pipeline with, say, a gerrit and a timer trigger.  So it's a multi-valued characteristic of a pipeline.  In fact, a pipeline with gerrit, github, zuul, and timer would be an unsurprising configuration to me.  How we actually manage displaying that will be interesting, but I agree it's interesting information to expose.

Thanks for the info, that all makes sense.  In the future, at least a brief mention of "why" in the commit message would be helpful.
What will both of these be used for?

The driver helps identify periodic pipelines (timer driver). This is used later to add an icon to pipelines in https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/810699 - I suppose we could do without it and it's not strictly related to admin features, but I thought a visual cue about how the difference between pipelines would be helpful to users.

The manager is needed when implementing promotes via the GUI. Promoting only makes sense on dependent pipelines; we show the promote action only for these pipelines in https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/781858/15/web/src/containers/status/Change.jsx#184

The default value could be defined in a different variable that is used if the key wasn't found in the dictionary.

I chose to keep the flask to emphasize the experimental aspect of this type of pipelines, but I am totally open to using CodeIcon instead!

I don't know about this one as I've never used the serial pipeline. But the first thing that comes in my mind when reading the description is something that reflects "parallel" or "concurrent" or "one-after-another".

IIUC it's actually "in order and one after another", as opposed to supercedent which is "in order but only the latest one". I'm not sure there's any icon from the patternfly pool that translates this well. Maybe the Sort Amount Down icon? https://fontawesome.com/icons/sort-amount-down

Let's use this for now. I'm a little worried that somebody could misinterpret the sorting icon as an "action" icon to sort things on the page, but maybe that's unsubstantiated since the icon is placed "somewhere in the middle of the page" and not in some toolbar or header.

I would like to see how this looks for a production CI system. And if we really face problems with this icon, we could still adapt it later on.
Maybe we could use the StreamIcon as default one https://fontawesome.com/icons/stream?style=solid? As this is also the icon I used for the pipeline in other places

1. I was just thinking if it is a good idea to put all the functionality into a single icon. Maybe it's better to just show the pipeline-specific icon add a second helper icon that provides the tooltip and the link to the zuul documentation.

This helper icon could be a greyed-out question-circle (https://fontawesome.com/v5.15/icons/question-circle?style=regular) icon that is placed right behind the pipeline name and wrapped into a <sup> tag (similar to the external link icon that is shown next to the "View log" link on the build result page).

Maybe you could use the ExternalLink component https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/web/src/Misc.jsx#L24 (which should provide most of the style) and just allow to override the icon.

I'm not sure if this adds to much noice to the status page, but I would give it a try.

2. It might be a good idea to ensure that external links are always opened in a new tab.
I followed your advice, except that I placed the helper icon next to the pipeline icon, because the info is related to the type of pipeline. Moving it around is of course no problem if you disagree.

I like the icon, but I think we should place it next to the pipeline name rather than between icon and pipeline name. Having an info icon next to another icon looks a little awkward in my opinion.

Although the icon is used to show the type of pipeline, I still see the icon more like an extension to the pipeline name, so I think it's fine to add the icon to the pipeline name rather than the type icon. I also think that most users are used to the pipeline names already (which in most cases already reflect different types of pipelines), we just had no icon to visualize this pipeline type so far.
Fair enough! The next PS will fix this.

zuul/zk/layout.py.message:
In scheduler.py we use this method a couple of times for getting the layout uuid from the LayoutState:

  layout_state = self.tenant_layout_state.get(tenant_name)
  layout_uuid = layout_state and layout_state.uuid

This means we can pass in a layout_state of False. In that case I think we should generate a new uuid? Otherwise we'll end up with False serialized uuids?

But also we want to generate a new uuid anytime we generate a brand new layout state in zookeeper and this would be the way to do that?

The layout UUID will not be False, but None.

This is basically a shorthand for:

    layout_uuid = layout_state.uuid if (layout_state and layout_state.uuid) else None

I understand this better now. Due to the code pattern I quoted above we get False as the layout_uuid then pass that through tenant parsing to where tenant parsing creates a Layout object. If the Layout objects gets a falsey value it creates a new uuid which we then assign to the new LayoutState.

Then later when we lookup the LayoutState again we'll find the preexisting layout.

just as a FYI. Instead of adding one instance entry per node you could also set profile by setting the default 'profile' at the role level.

- name: Controller
  count: 3
  defaults:
    profile: control
- name: Compute
  count: 2
  defaults:
    profile: compute
- name: Ceph
  count: 2
  defaults:
    profile: ceph
this way the control-0 will end up as overcloud-control-0. With the suggestion the control-0 may end up as a overcloud-control-2.

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/zuul/build/96d222c7f0554b01a783ab9005459473/log/job-output.txt#11047 shows us governing during a failed test. Logging doesn't report every failure after that but I suspect at least part of the issue is we are evaluating things too slowly? That said system load may also be a slow to update value?

That last failure was due to high system load: https://zuul.opendev.org/t/zuul/build/1549250827ff4d9ebc149b10e8ac36eb/log/job-output.txt#10910 and we never seemed to drop off low enough after that to reregister. I suspect that polling more frequently isn't fixing this.

We might need to disable the sensors in testing instead? But that causes sensor specific tests to fail which means we need to do a bit more work in that space.

There as another failure due to this problem [1].

Judging from the discussion here I think we have the following possibilities:
1. disable sensors in test
2. tweak sensor parameters in test (probably increase executor.load_multiplier in the zuul.conf test fixtures)
3. increase all the timeouts where we wait for jobs
4. reduce concurrency
5. larger nodes

So I guess we decide against #1 it seems to me that probably the easiest thing would be to try out #2.

zuul/model.py.message:
Thinking out loud here would it be safer to serialize and deserialize these queues with an explicit association rather than inferring it from a project + branch name?

I wonder what would happen if you reconfigure to move a project from one queue to another and that doesn't get serialized properly due to an outage. I guess the second scheduler would read the old data and reconcile it against the new config and then write that out to zookeeper? So for a (short) period of time you may run the old config for queues?

https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/814773/ hints at the expected behavior here if there is a failure. Basically to move the shared state would have to be updated. This means if sched1 fails then the project hasn't moved yet and sched2 can recover things and do the move. We shouldn't flip flop. For this reason this code should be sufficient.

zuul/model.py.message:
It seems like we should do this so the atomicity/rollback is as-expected:
state.updateAttributes(ctx, queues=self.state.queues + [queue])

Or mirror what we do below in removeQueue and:
with ctx:
  state.queue.sapped(queue)

I see self.queues as being an external-facing compat shim; I think I like that internally we're using the real object; to me it seems more clear and is a good reminder of the split between in-memory layout object and ZK state representation.

To avoid confusion it would be nice if we could add and get from objects symmetrically. self.queues is a property defined as returning self.state.queues. Can we use self.state.queues or self.queues for both operations?

So, I was debugging with Alfredo.  A few summary points:

- DevStack currently defaults to "cpu_mode=none", which on non-KVM systems translate to "qemu64" CPU model
- RHEL9 / CentOS9 GCC switch to x86_64-v2[1]
- And "qemu64" CPU model (which is awful for many reasons[2]) will not work with x86_64-v2
- So for CentOS9 (and any other systems that's switching to x86_64-v2), either don't set `cpu_mode` at all in DevStack, in which case, Nova will default to libvirt's "host-model" CPU mode.  Or: come up with a bespoke model that'll work across.

PS: One reason why DevStack defaults to "cpu_mode=none" (which means "qemu64") is that it lets one live-migrate regardless of host CPUs ... 


[1] https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2021/01/05/building-red-hat-enterprise-linux-9-for-the-x86-64-v2-microarchitecture-level#
[2] https://kashyapc.fedorapeople.org/Secure-CPU-config-for-KVM-based-guests-RHT_TechDay_Brussels_2020.pdf

This is super useful thank you. Now for some background on why devstack does what it does. The tl;dr is Nova Live Migration testing. A single cloud may give us multiple instances with different host CPUs.

When we first started to set up Nova Live Migration testing this was a big issue. To address this the first thing I tried was a custom qemu CPU, but due to bugs in nova/libvirt/qemu (I forget exactly where) the custom CPU model was completely ignored. Eventually (and I think it was kashyap who helped solve this at the time) we realized we could use a consistent cpu model of qemu64 by not setting a value at all.

What this means for Devstack is that we need to be careful about changing this default. DIB jobs could override and set up a model specific to those jobs; however, the DIB jobs install a "default" devstack and don't attempt to get too fancy so I think we should avoid this. Eventually devstack will likely need to address this directly anyway.

Probably the best thing would be for devstack (or nova?) to default to an x86_64-v2 CPU model. I suspect that qemu doesn't actually define one of these? Perhaps CentOS/RHEL 9 should try and correct this issue in those tools before they bump up their CPU requirements? Note, I don't expect them to change course at this point, but do think it is reasonable to try and update those tools in the interim.

The last thing we should try to do is set a custom CPU model. It never worked for us in the past and I don't have high hopes it will be a fun experience today. But if it doesn't work that is still a bug and we can push on that.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: you need to have linebreak between commit "summary" and "details"

This information isn't part of the commit *message*: it's part of the commit. This information is included automatically. The author fields indicate who "authored" the commit initially, while the the commit fields indicate who made the last changes (i.e. a rebase or amend operation). You can reset the authorship information using e.g. 'git commit --amend --reset-author'.

As I said, this information is set automatically based on your local git config (i.e. 'git config user.name' and 'git config user.email'): the author info is added when you create a commit and the commit info is added when you make a change. You don't need to/can't set this information manually. Gerrit just surfaces that information so it's visible.

I added a linebreak. Then I noticed there are these information in one of your commit:
Parent:     ff372ffd (Add Python3 yoga unit tests)
Author:     Artem Goncharov <Artem.goncharov@gmail.com>
AuthorDate: 2020-11-19 18:15:55 +0100
Commit:     Artem Goncharov <Artem.goncharov@gmail.com>
CommitDate: 2021-10-08 11:56:05 +0200
Could you teach me how to get this information into our commits in the future.

You don't need to track this information in the commit message: we have the history in Gerrit. Instead, try to write from the perspective of someone looking at git log many years later, trying to figure out what you did. Something like this, perhaps:

  Switch the 'server backup' command to SDK

  Switch this command from novaclient to SDK. As this is the first server-related
  command that we are migrating, we need to extend our test fakes to support fake
  Server resources.

  command
  -s

or use the 'venv' tox environment:
 
  $ tox -e venv -- reno new migrate-server-backup-to-sdk

The former is probably faster if you're using reno regularly, but the latter is "cleaner" since you're not installing anything system wide. Your call. You could also create a virtualenv locally and install in there.

One additional question: how are you reworking these commits? I suspect you're doing it in the web UI, which is fine, but it can be faster to pull things down and work on them locally. For example, to correct an issue in the commit message:

  git review -d 814332
  git commit --amend
  # make changes
  git review -f

Note that the '-f' flag passed to git review means "delete" my local branch - you don't really need to keep local branches around once they're under review, since you can always pull the latest version from Gerrit if/when you need to rework something.

Thanks for the explanation I think I got it now

The main goal is to test the expected cloud-config via tempest configuration instead of automatically detecting what is there is cloud return. With the desired configured extensions (or any other config like resize is enabled or not) in Tempest, the test will assert if service API returns that way otherwise fail. For example, if list extensions API does not return 'port-resource-request-groups (due to some neutron erorr or misconfiguration in cloud) then we will assert different API responses, and test will pass. And if we use Tempest configured extensions that have 'port-resource-request-groups' then the test will fail as expected.

zuul/zk/job_request_queue.py.message: Do we need to get the children as part of the transaction as well? That way we don't get_children with a short list and fail to delete path below because one of its children remain?

The transactions are basically write only; it's basically zk operations bundled into one.  So there's no opportunity to get data back from that one operation (you can, however, embed stat checks in it, so you can ensure nodes are still up to date).  In this way, it differs from a SQL transaction.

Put another way, the transaction() method doesn't do anything on the server.  The only interaction with the server is the commit() method, which is all-or-none.

This behavior is pretty close to the existing recursive delete which just lists children then deletes them and the parent (but goes >1 level deep; we only need 1).  This isn't perfect, but should work most of the time.  It will prevent the issue with isLocked because that checks the parent before trying to create the children.  It won't prevent a case where two workers try to lock at the same time and then one of them finishes the job before the other one cleans up its failed lock attempt.  The chance of that happening is vanishingly small, but I guess we'll see if it shows up in the unit tests.

BTW, failure here is harmless -- this was just tripping our "is ZK clean" check at the end of test runs.

puppet-manifests/debian/deb_folder/rules.message:
nit: remove whitespace at the end of the line

Why are we doing this? The CentOS package installs this in /etc/puppet as well. Trying to understand why we are deviating.

Looking a bit deeper, debian ships only a conffile, its puppet itself shipping a default hiera.yaml. We will need puppet to stop doing this:

https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/commit/7178bf1850c1addc40b5cc31a29aa4add09f34a9

Looks like the CentOS puppet package did not install a default hiera.yaml file, so we didn't have a conflict there.

I think we need to patch the puppet-5.5.22 package to drop debian/conffiles/hiera.yaml so that this package can install to /etc/puppet. This version contains the hierarchy and datadir that aligns with our implementation and puppet-manifest-apply.sh

The puppet package in Debian ships its own /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml by default so when puppet is installed first and then puppet-manifest the install will fail because dpkg will prevent the package to install because /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml already exists. And its a conffile.

Copying here from the bug, Tobias suggested another alternative, my feedback is:

Actually I think setting state report rpc timeout to report_interval makes sense: it's not heavy for the server and if there is no response during report_interval likely there is something wrong with the server and there is not much sense to wait more."
I've answered with more details in launchpad bug.

Instead of this I would use PluginReportStateAPI.report_state() with "use_call=False".

Why the agent should wait for the RPC response? If the agent reports is missed by the server, another report will be sent in the next "AGENT.report_interval".

I would like other people to check this idea before creating a new config var.

To me it looks like a workaround of rpc messaging timeout during rabbit restart.
Need to investigate if this timeout could be avoided (like error raised on rabbit restart) from messaging side before adding yet another rpc timeout config knob in neutron.

Trying to get some of our internal fixes upstream in a more cleaner way with this.

Perhaps there is a better way than modifying PluginReportStateAPI so that this would be more backport-friendly, if that's the case please let me know 😊

Then my proposal of using cast makes more sense. "cast" won't block the agent. If the server receives this message (if it is not discarded by the MQ), the server can send, if needed, a "agent_revived" status. Of course, that implies a new API method between server and agent.

I prefer that approach rather than adding a new variable just for this specific timeout.

Yes, and despite this we have a problem with this initial sync when rebooting too many agents or in loaded systems.

This feature will delay the problem. Increasing timeouts is not the solution.

I still think we should:
- Move calls to cast.
- RPC (client and server) should implement a method to inform to the agent this status (agent revived).

This communication should be async, the agent should not wait for a confirmation. And ultimately, if that happens, admin should manually disable some agents allowing the others to properly restart.
It's not only for rabbit, it's for neutron-server restarted as well.

I personally agree with opinion that using e.g. 5 minutes timeout for the heartbeats don't makes sense really. And I also agree with Oleg's proposal of using report_interval as timeout in that case to avoid new config option.
IMO that could be an option for now and I think we can backport it even to stable branches. This would actually just make things to work "properly" as even if someone already set rpc_timeout to e.g. 300 seconds, that's not correct for heartbeat messages, right?

@Rodolfo - I think we can explore switching those heartbeats to cast again but this probably can be bigger change and will require exploring what we can break by doing that 😊

So from me +1 for Oleg's proposal.

It's the other way around, this decreases the RPC timeout (given that rpc_response_timeout=60 and report_interval=30 by default, but the important part here is that the interval is decoupled from rpc_response_timeout).

We have a very large amount of routers (taking L3 agent as example now) and need to increase rpc_response_timeout from default 60 seconds to 5 minutes because RPC messages will timeout because neutron-server is to slow to compose the answer to the RPC call getting all routers.

The rpc_response_timeout is also used for the report_state RPC call() which doesn't make sense. If a neutron-server is restarted at the same time an agent is mid RPC call() the message will timeout because n-server will not reply.

The agent will wait for 5 minutes (due to rpc_response_timeout) and during that time n-server will set the agent as down because agent_down_time has expired. Note that this only applies to the thread running the report_state RPC call()'s, the agent is happily looping and applying state without any issues.

When those 5 minutes has passed, the agent will try report_state RPC call() again and successfully update it's state with n-server, agent will be considered revived (even though it has synced it's state all the time, only report_state thread was "hung" due to the blocking timeout) and *all* resources on the L3 agent will be resynced.

From what I understand based on Oleg's link there is that the use of cast in report_state is intentional.

Thanks for your feedback, I think using report_interval is the solution for now also considering (ops hat on) that it would also be up for consideration being backported to stable branches.

I think Rodolfo has the best solution moving forward but would require more work regarding the RPC layer which would be something that can be backported.

I will work more on this proposal and let you know once it's in a working/reviewable state. Thanks!
PoC, probably not functional as if AGENT is not set it will raise.
The reason I wanted a configuration option the first time is because I wanted the possibility of backporting the behavior since we are carrying custom patches.
Except for the unit test failure, I'm assuming some testing (functionals?) might have a very low report_interval causing failures.
Let's see if we can get some more feedback.
